awd_titl_txt: NRT-DESE: Interdisciplinary Graduate Training to Understand and Inform Decision Processes Using Advanced Spatial Data Analysis and Visualization
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award to SUNY at Stony Brook will provide science and engineering graduate students with unique interdisciplinary skills to assist and eventually lead in the translation of complex data-enabled research into informed decisions and sound policies. Within all sectors of industry and government, effective decision making depends on the ability of scientists to interpret data and communicate results in a way that supports the decision-making process. This new training program responds to this challenge with an interdisciplinary set of new courses and a suite of activities united by the theme of "Scientific Training and Research to Inform DEcisions" (STRIDE). It specifically will include the rarely explicitly taught skills of decision support, such as understanding the perspectives of stakeholders, science communication, and translating scientific uncertainty. The project anticipates training 90 PhD students, including at least 20 funded doctoral trainees, and a similar number of non-trainee MS and PhD students that will participate in program components from the departments of atmospheric and marine sciences, ecology and evolution, computer science, biomedical informatics, applied mathematics and statistics, journalism, and advanced computational science. 

STRIDE will initially target environmental sustainability (including climate change, marine ecology and natural resource management, and illegal deforestation) and energy sustainability, and will add population health in the third year. Research in advanced visual data analytics to support decisions will be pervasive in all areas. The cross fertilization between disciplines focused on decision making will prepare students to make discoveries in the domain sciences and will lead to innovations in visual data analytics. To develop research skills in new contexts and to diversify career perspectives, trainees will have summer externships at non-academic partners such as IBM Research, Brookhaven National Laboratory, and the National Marine Fisheries Service, with new partners being added each year. The program comprises three major components: 1) a set of specially designed courses on decision support, spatial data analysis, visualization, and communication required for all students; 2) training in a STEM domain discipline; and 3) a set of non-course-based program elements in which all students will participate, including recruitment, skill development, professional development, and personal development. In addition to degrees in their domain-science disciplines, students will receive a graduate certificate from STRIDE after completing the three proposed courses and program activities. Specific innovations to be tested by rigorous evaluation include the seminar course in scientific decision support that will feature many government/industry scientists, decision makers, and journalists remotely leading discussions on the science, societal, and other challenges associated with decision support in their respective fields. Another new course focusing on science communication for decision makers will be provided by the Alan Alda Center for Communicating Science in the School of Journalism.

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Traineeship Track is dedicated to effective training of STEM graduate students in high priority interdisciplinary research areas, through the comprehensive traineeship model that is innovative, evidence-based, and aligned with changing workforce and research needs.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of STRIDE was to provide STEM graduate students with interdisciplinary skills required to assist, create, and lead the translation of complex data-enabled research into informed decisions and sound policies. The skills needed include those traditionally taught to science students such as data analytics and visualization, but also skills supporting decision-making (understanding the perspectives of various stakeholders, science communication, and translating scientific uncertainty). Another major goal was to increase the enrollment of underrepresented populations in the sciences, including underrepresented minority (URM) groups and female students, through partnership with Stony Brook’s Center for Inclusive Education (CIE). The outcome of this partnership resulted in 26 funded fellows (18, female; 26, male). Of the 26, four identified as URM. Participants include an additional 13 female trainees who were not funded by NSF.

Through STRIDE, a multi-level mentoring model was initiated providing trainees with an interdisciplinary faculty mentor and peer mentor. With this model, trainees work with both their research advisors as well as a STRIDE faculty mentor in a differing discipline. These collaborations have strengthened trainees' abilities and research through the fortification of broader research abilities. For example, Dr. Kristjan Mets (previously funded, Ecology and Evolution) who studies bats, was able to strengthen his programming abilities through his mentorship by Prof. Erez Zadok (Computer Science). Concurrently, Mets was involved with research within the Dávalos lab, modeling deforestation through time in complex landscapes and generating forecasts. Because of this work, they can now trace the effects of particular policies through time and separate proximate agents of deforestation from structural causes such as policies.

Internship opportunities arranged by STRIDE allowed trainees to use their research abilities in broader ways. Internship partners included National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), Antarctic and Southern Ocean Coalition (ASOC), and Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL). Dr. Joshua Comden, a formerly funded trainee from Applied Math and Science completed an internship with the Alliance for Sustainable Energy (where he subsequently was hired for employment upon graduating) and Dr. Megan Hahn (previously funded), from Marine Science completed her internship with Dr. Luis Marcos Raymundo, a physician at Stony Brook University Hospital, where she developed protocols, ran experiments, and analyzed and presented data about new tick borne pathogens.

Near-term ecological forecasting is an emerging interdisciplinary research area focused on accelerating environmental research and making it more relevant to society. Former STRIDE trainees, Julia Stepanuk and Dr. Kristjan Mets had the opportunity to attend the Ecological Forecasting Initiative conference in Washington, D.C., an event that served as the official launch of the Ecological Forecasting Initiative, a major interdisciplinary effort to bring cutting-edge forecasting and data-model synthesis tools to pressing ecological and resource management challenges. Former STRIDE Fellow, Rachael Herman was selected for a NASA Future Investigators in NASA Earth and Space Science and Technology (FINESST) Award. Rachael’s research proposal focusing on Gentoo penguins was one of 62 selected out of a pool of 789 total proposals (341 in Earth Science) and will provide substantial funding for the next three years.

Logan Graham completed an internship at Castleton Commodities International where he served as a Financial Transmission Rights Quantitative Research Intern by leveraging his mathematics and programming backgrounds developing software solutions for identifying mispriced energy-related commodities.

Stephanie Taboada was selected in the Future Leaders in Policy competition sponsored by the Rockefeller Institute which showcases the best of SUNY undergraduate and graduate research related to public policy from a range of fields. Stephanie presented her research, Potential of Renewable Natural Gas (RNG) to Decarbonize New York's Energy System. The competition gave participants opportunities for professional skills development and networking.

Anna McPherran obtained a grant from the NSF INTERN program to produce an educational website in collaboration with the New York Hall of Science called connecttheclues.com. Her STRIDE training in science communication and data visualization supported her in that endeavor.

Due to the success of the STRIDE project, the Institute for Advanced Computational Science was able to secure additional funds from an anonymous endower to continue the STRIDE program, scaled down for all IACS students. We will continue to offer professional development opportunities to students through such programs as brown bag seminars, interdisciplinary mentoring, and trainings in data visualization and science communication.
